intro: Macvaughiella mexicana var. standleyi, commonly known as the Mexican standley's macvaughiella, is a rare and specialized plant native to specific regions of Mexico. It is characterized by its unique morphological features, including its small, clustered leaves and distinctive flowering structures. This variant belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and shares some floral characteristics with its relatives. It thrives in tropical and subtropical environments, often in well-drained soils. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a species of conservation interest.
